newsitem.title: USA: Georgia declares emergency, urges evacuations.
newsitem.headline: Georgia declares emergency, urges evacuations.

text.p: Georgia Governor Zell Miller declared a state of emergency in 11 counties along and near the Georgia coast on Wednesday and officials began urging evacuations in anticipation of Hurricane Fran.
Miller's executive order made "all resources of the State of Georgia" available to local officials to assist in hurricane response and recovery.
The governor declared a state of emergency in Camden, Glynn, McIntosh, Liberty, Bryan, Chatham, Charlton, Brantley, Wayne, Long and Effingham counties.
In Savannah, the Chatham County Commission urged some residents to evacuate voluntarily and said it might require evacuations as Hurricane Fran approached.

"We're under a voluntary evacuation for outlying islands and waterfront property, low-lying areas and mobile homes," said Randy Hecht of the Chatham County Emergency Management Agency. The Cumberland Island National Seashore in southeast Georgia was closed to visitors.

It was the second time this summer that Georgia's coastal areas had braced for a hurricane. The coastline north of Brunswick was placed under a hurricane warning as Hurricane Bertha passed about 150 miles east of Savannah on thenight of July 11. The storm displaced athletes competing in Olympic yachting events.
